As a paladin, you gain the following class features.

Hit Points

Hit Dice: 1d10 per paladin level
Hit Points at 1st Level: 10 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d10 (or 6) + your Constitution modifier per paladin level after 1st

Proficiencies

Armor: All armor, shields
Weapons: Simple weapons, martial weapons
Tools: None
Saving Throws: Wisdom, Charisma
Skills: Choose two from Athletics, Insight, Intimidation, Medicine, Persuasion, and Religion

Equipment

You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

  • (a) a @Compendium[5e-complete-fr.5e-journals.SPzXa5i5cD7tZ1b9]{martial weapon} and a @Compendium[5e-complete-fr.5e-items.w9XbCvmgPpXFRrnp]{shield} or (b) two @Compendium[5e-complete-fr.5e-journals.SPzXa5i5cD7tZ1b9]{martial weapons}
  • (a) five @Compendium[5e-complete-fr.5e-items.cB98aK4i7wWSOYh1]{javelins} or (b) @Compendium[5e-complete-fr.5e-journals.SPzXa5i5cD7tZ1b9]{any simple weapon}
  • (a) a @Compendium[5e-complete-fr.5e-items.QLzgZU2MlxvR7qZj]{priest's pack} or (b) a @Compendium[5e-complete-fr.5e-items.DndDRdbpbQp6Ey5i]{explorer's pack}
  • @Compendium[5e-complete-fr.5e-items.SnQfDljS7TU7n6Mh]{chain mail} and a holy symbol

Alternatively, you can roll [[/roll 8d4 * 10]] gp and buy all your equipment.

Note: This is a rebalanced roll calculated by thinkdm.org. The canon roll is [[/roll 5d4 * 10]].

The Paladin

Clad in plate armor that gleams in the sun despite the dust and grime of a long journey, a human lays down his sword and shield and places his hands on a mortally wounded man. Divine radiance flows from his hands, the man's wounds close, and his eyes open wide in amazement.

A dwarf hides behind an outcrop, his black cloak rendering him nearly invisible in the night, and watches a warband of orcs celebrating their recent victory. Silently, he slips among them and whispers an oath, and two orcs are dead before they realize he is there.

Silver hair glints in a beam of light that seems to illuminate only him, an elf laughs with exhilaration. His spear gleams like his eyes as he strikes again and again at a twisted giant, until finally his light overcomes the creature's hideous darkness.

Whatever their origin and mission, paladins are united by their oaths to stand against the forces of evil. Whether sworn before an altar of god and witnessed by a priest, in a sacred grove before nature spirits and fey beings, or in a moment of despair and grief with the dead as their only witnesses, a paladin's oath is a powerful bond. It is a source of power that transforms a devout warrior into a blessed champion.

The Quest for Justice

A paladin swears to uphold justice and righteousness, to stand with the good things in the world against the encroaching darkness, and to hunt the forces of evil wherever they lurk. Different paladins focus on various aspects of the quest for justice, but all are bound by the oaths that grant them the power to accomplish their sacred work. While many paladins are devoted to good gods, the power of a paladin comes as much from a commitment to justice itself as from a god.

Paladins train for years to learn the skills of combat, mastering a variety of weapons and armors. Even so, their martial skills are secondary to the magical power they wield: the power to heal the sick and injured, to strike down the wicked and the undead, and to protect the innocent and those who join them in the fight for justice.

Beyond the Ordinary

Almost by definition, a paladin's life is a life of adventure. Unless sidelined by a lasting injury, every paladin lives on the front lines of the cosmic battle against evil. Warriors are rare even among the ranks of militias and armies of the world, but even fewer can claim the true calling of a paladin. When they receive the call, these warriors turn their backs on their old lives and take up arms to fight evil. Sometimes, their oaths lead them into service to the crown as leaders of elite groups of knights, but even then, their loyalty goes first to the cause of justice, not to the crown and country.

Adventuring paladins take their work seriously. A descent into an ancient ruin or a dusty crypt can be a quest driven by a purpose higher than the acquisition of treasure. Evil lurks in dungeons and primordial forests, and even the smallest victory against it can tip the cosmic balance away from oblivion.

Multiclassing

If your group uses the optional multiclassing rules in the Player's Handbook, here is what you need to know if you choose paladin as one of your classes.

Minimum ability score. As a multiclass character, you must have at least a 13 Strength or Charisma score to take a level in this class, or to take a level in another class if you are already a paladin.

Proficiencies gained. If paladin isn't your initial class, here are the proficiencies you gain when you take your first level as a paladin: light armor, medium armor, shields, simple weapons, martial weapons.

Spell slots. You are a half spellcaster. Add half your paladin levels (rounded down) to the appropriate levels of other classes to determine your available spell slots.

Please refer to the @UUID[Compendium.5e-complete-fr.5e-journals.a5xwmx4d5X1FHEct]{Multiclassing Rules} for more information on multiclassing.
